messages.text: Considering how fast Julia is, it's disappointing that it lacks a lot of functionality for eliding allocations: No reading each line into a buffer, no string splitting without allocations, `map` and `filter` is eager, AFAIK there is no mutable `AbstractString` , etc.

messages.text: Oof, trying to start using VS Code now and everything missing from Juno is :cry: . Today's: lost a computation because the remote usage doesn't use tmux by default. It's getting close but it still has an edge. Still hoping to transition by this summer.

messages.text: Google presenting olddddd documentation versions of Julia packages as the top result. It feels like the internet is gaslighting you sometimes. (<@U69BL50BF> in this case, top result for "julia DiffEq" links to v2.0 of the docs) Second result fortunately is correct, but I can't help but think how many new-to-Julia people are less impressed by the docs from nearly 4 years ago....!

messages.text: It is agonizing (and somewhat amusing) that Julia doesn't have `rref` built into Base.LinearAlgebra at the moment and that it was removed ~5 years ago (if I can count right). It definitely spoils the experience of using Julia for some quick linalg calculations.

elements.text: It is agonizing (and somewhat amusing) that Julia doesn't have
built into Base.LinearAlgebra at the moment and that it was removed ~5 years ago (if I can count right). It definitely spoils the experience of using Julia for some quick linalg calculations.

messages.text: It does hold high importance in linalg though it might not be as useful in numerical computing. But it is just as important to being able to computationally cross-check hand calculations

elements.text: It does hold high importance in linalg though it might not be as useful in numerical computing. But it is just as important to being able to computationally cross-check hand calculations

messages.text:
Am I timing TTFP wrong?
Julia 1.0
```
julia> @time (using Plots; display(plot(1:0.1:10, sin.(1:0.1:10))))
 23.029167 seconds (52.21 M allocations: 2.723 GiB, 5.60% gc time)```
Julia 1.6
```
julia> @time (using Plots; display(plot(1:0.1:10, sin.(1:0.1:10))))
 20.384380 seconds (60.73 M allocations: 3.559 GiB, 6.93% gc time)```
Like technically it is better.
But not by much?

elements.text:
Am I timing TTFP wrong?
Julia 1.0

julia> @time (using Plots; display(plot(1:0.1:10, sin.(1:0.1:10))))
 23.029167 seconds (52.21 M allocations: 2.723 GiB, 5.60% gc time)

julia> @time (using Plots; display(plot(1:0.1:10, sin.(1:0.1:10))))
 20.384380 seconds (60.73 M allocations: 3.559 GiB, 6.93% gc time)

Like technically it is better.
But not by much?

messages.text:
Also time to 2nd plot:
Look at all that extra compliation???
this on relatively recent 1.7/master
```
julia> @time (using Plots; display(plot(1:0.1:10, sin.(1:0.1:10))))
 19.381677 seconds (61.36 M allocations: 3.594 GiB, 7.87% gc time)

julia> @time (using Plots; display(plot(1:0.1:10, sin.(1:0.1:10))))
  0.520393 seconds (638.88 k allocations: 34.788 MiB, 4.08% gc time, 97.41% compilation time)

julia> @time (using Plots; display(plot(1:0.1:10, sin.(1:0.1:10))))
  0.016332 seconds (47.91 k allocations: 1.356 MiB)```

messages.text:
Julia Syndrome :sneezing_face:-- _worrying about the performance of one's app before one even starts seeing problems._
Terminal Pre-Julia Syndrome :skull:-- _worrying about the performance of one's app so badly that one never gets around to writing it._

elements.text: worrying about the performance of one's app before one even starts seeing problems.
worrying about the performance of one's app so badly that one never gets around to writing it.

messages.text: I do this way too much.  It's part of my more general problem with excessive planning getting in the way of ever actually doing anything.  Spend so much time thinking about how to make the initial implementation of something absolutely perfect that I just never do it

elements.text: I do this way too much.  It's part of my more general problem with excessive planning getting in the way of ever actually doing anything.  Spend so much time thinking about how to make the initial implementation of something absolutely perfect that I just never do it

messages.text:
One way to getting around this I find is to not stress too much about having to re-write parts of your code.

Step 1: Write your code to the best of your ability.
Step 2: Benchmark, does it need optimizing?
Step 3: Optimize if optimization is needed.

More often than not, getting a working program up and running is more valuable than being meticulous with performance gains.

elements.text:
One way to getting around this I find is to not stress too much about having to re-write parts of your code.

Step 1: Write your code to the best of your ability.
Step 2: Benchmark, does it need optimizing?
Step 3: Optimize if optimization is needed.

More often than not, getting a working program up and running is more valuable than being meticulous with performance gains.

messages.text: My laptop fan makes horrible noise louder than an electric tooth brush. Now i opened up my laptop and unplugged the fan header. However now i can't reboot without  screw driver in hand, since the fan header needs to be present on startup.

Yet another unicode gripe
```julia> subscript(n) = join(Char(0x2080 + parse(Int, d)) for d in string(n))

julia> superscript(n) = join(Char(0x2070 + parse(Int, d)) for d in string(n))

julia> subscript(1234567890)
"₁₂₃₄₅₆₇₈₉₀"

julia> superscript(1234567890)
"ⁱ\u2072\u2073⁴⁵⁶⁷⁸⁹⁰"```

elements.text:
julia> subscript(n) = join(Char(0x2080 + parse(Int, d)) for d in string(n))

julia> superscript(n) = join(Char(0x2070 + parse(Int, d)) for d in string(n))

julia> subscript(1234567890)
"₁₂₃₄₅₆₇₈₉₀"

julia> superscript(1234567890)
"ⁱ\u2072\u2073⁴⁵⁶⁷⁸⁹⁰"

messages.text: `Float16` is just kind of broken. Our method for converting `Float64` to `Float16` truncates instead of rounding

elements.text: is just kind of broken. Our method for converting

messages.text: Huh?
It should not?
`Float16(.999755)` returns `Float16(0.9995)` instead of `Float16(1.0)`
it actually isn't truncating, it's just wrong for some values. `Float16(.9999)` correctly returns `Float16(1.0)`

elements.text: it actually isn't truncating, it's just wrong for some values.

messages.text: AFAICT that actually isn’t wrong — it’s because Float16(0.9995) isn’t _actually_ 0.9995 (AKA 0.9995000….) in decimal. Because floats aren’t actually decimal.

elements.text: AFAICT that actually isn’t wrong — it’s because Float16(0.9995) isn’t
0.9995 (AKA 0.9995000….) in decimal. Because floats aren’t actually decimal.

messages.text: Float16(0.9995) in actual decimals is actually ~closer to~ 0.99951171875

elements.text: Float16(0.9995) in actual decimals is actually

messages.text: It's exactly that decimal

```julia> big(prevfloat(Float16(1.0)))
0.99951171875```
The fact that there are no more decimals means that it’s this exact decimal
